metadata.case_name: Candidates in Writ Petitions Nos. 618 to 622 of 1970 v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 619 passed Secondary School Leaving examination in March 1968 obtaining first class marks.

Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 619 passed Pre-University Course Examination held by Bangalore University in March 1969 securing 67 marks in optional subjects Physics, Chemistry and Biology, and 71 marks in aggregate.

Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 619 passed B.Sc. Part I examination held by Karnatak University securing first class marks, making her eligible for admission to medical course under Ordinance 144A of Karnatak University.
Three universities in Mysore State: Karnatak, Mysore, and Bangalore. Karnatak requires B.Sc. Part I for MBBS eligibility; others require Pre-Professional examination equivalent to it.

State conducts four government medical colleges with 765 seats: Mysore (Mysore Univ), Bangalore (Bangalore Univ), Hubli and Bellary (Karnatak Univ). Private colleges with government control over some seats.
State Government framed Mysore Medical Colleges Selection for Admission Rules, 1970 regulating admissions to government medical colleges and 59 seats in private colleges.
Petitioner in WP 619 applied to selection committee for admission to medical colleges affiliated to Karnatak University but was not selected.
Rule 2: Eligibility - passed PUC or equivalent with Physics, Chemistry, Biology or graduates with those subjects, specified marks, age limit. 80% seats for PUC passers, 20% for graduates.

Rule 4: 60 seats set apart for categories like students from Union territories without medical colleges, less developed Commonwealth countries, Nepal, repatriates, defence personnel children, LAMS/LUMS passers, lady students in family planning, political sufferers children, Goa students.
Rule 5: After deducting Rule 4 seats, 15% for Scheduled Castes, 3% Scheduled Tribes, 30% socially and educationally backward classes.
Rule 9(1): Seats distributed university-wise, but up to 20% discretionary for other universities in State or India.
Petitioner in WP 619 had 67 marks in optional subjects in PUC from Bangalore University; students with lesser marks from Karnatak University colleges got admission.

Petitioner in WP 621 born August 2, 1954 at Bellary (Mysore since 1953), father transferred to Andhra Pradesh April 1954, retired June 1970. Passed SSLC 1968-69 Cuddappah first class, PUC 1969-70 Venkateswara University 150/200 optional (75%), total 389/600 (65%).

Petitioner in WP 621 applied July 22, 1970 for Karnatak University colleges, interview card K-20, not selected October 6, 1970. Last admitted in general pool Bellary and Hubli had 295/450 (65.6%) from Karnatak University.
Rule 3: Eligible if Indian citizen, domiciled in Mysore, resident for at least 10 years prior to application.
Petitioner WP 621 had certificate from Tehsildar Bellary for 10 years residence, but studied in AP after 1963; father claimed vacations in Bellary.
Petitioner in WP 622 passed B.Sc. Bangalore University 1969 with 505/1000 (50.5%), applied July 23, 1970 for Pre-Professional Course, not selected.

Rule 4(h): 15 seats for children of political sufferers defined as those who suffered imprisonment/detention >=6 months, capital punishment, died in jail, killed/incapacitated by police/military, lost job/property/livelihood due to participation in national movement for India's emancipation.

legal_issues.text: Whether State Government can frame rules depriving petitioner of admission despite eligibility under university Ordinance 144A of Karnatak University.
Whether Rule 9(1) providing university-wise distribution of seats is discriminatory and violates Article 14.
Whether reservations under Rules 4 and 5 are excessive and violate Article 15(4).
Whether Rule 3 requiring 10 years residence in Mysore is arbitrary and discriminatory (WP 621).
Whether Rule 4(h) reserving seats for children of political sufferers is vague, ambiguous, fanciful, politically oriented without intelligible differentia or rational nexus (WP 622).

petitioner_arguments.text: Once eligible under university ordinances, State cannot make rules depriving admission.
University-wise distribution under Rule 9(1) discriminatory without rational basis, violates Art. 14; students with higher marks denied due to university affiliation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Rajendran v. Madras; Periakaruppan v. Tamil Nadu

petitioner_arguments.text: Reservations under Rules 4 and 5 excessive beyond permitted by Court decisions, violate Art. 15(4).
Rule 3's 10-year residence requirement arbitrary; petitioner domiciled and resided sufficiently; higher marks in optional subjects than selected students.
Rule 4(h) vague ('political sufferer', 'national movement'); fanciful category without nexus to merit-based admission.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Surendrakumar v. State; other High Court cases

respondent_arguments.text: Government maintains colleges from public funds, has power to regulate admissions consistent with university eligibility standards.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Andhra Pradesh v. Lavu Narendranath; Chitra Ghosh v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: University-wise distribution valid classification with rational nexus to cater to regional educational needs; discretion for 20% outsiders; different university standards.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Chitra Ghosh v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 4 sets sources, not reservation; Rule 5 reservation 48/720 (~6.7%) not shown excessive; Art. 15(4) permits for backward classes.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 15(4); Balaji v. Mysore; Periakaruppan v. Tamil Nadu

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner WP621 did not satisfy 10-year residence; marks not comparable across universities; total marks 65% vs 65.6%.
Rule 4(h) definition clear, detailed; category justified as handicapped like defence personnel children; nexus to fair distribution.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Chitra Ghosh v. Union of India; Subhashini v. State

court_reasoning.text: University ordinances set minimum eligibility, not entitlement to admission; Government can regulate admissions in its institutions without inconsistency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Eligibility does not mean automatic right to admission commensurate with seats.

court_reasoning.text: University-wise distribution valid; universities serve regional needs; not like district/unit-wise; discretion for 20% outsiders; different standards across universities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification has rational nexus to cater to university-attached candidates' needs; distinguishable from Rajendran and Periakaruppan.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 4 sources, not reservation; Rule 5 ~6.7% not shown excessive; no materials to prove unreasonableness.
WP621 petitioner lacks 10-year continuous residence; marks not comparable (optional vs total, different unis); not equally situated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination only for equally situated; academic as not entitled even without Rule 3.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 4(h) definition clear, unambiguous; category valid like defence children; handicap from parents' suffering justifies preference for fair distribution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intelligible differentia with nexus to object of equitable seats.

court_reasoning.text: Dua J. refrains on Rule 4(h) validity but petitioner WP622 marks lower than last political sufferer child admitted; not entitled.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unnecessary to decide as petitioner lacks merit claim.

holdings.text: Government has power to frame admission rules consistent with university eligibility.
Rule 9(1) university-wise distribution not violative of Art. 14.
Petition WP621 fails on merits and residence.
Rule 4(h) valid (Shelat J.); unnecessary to decide (Dua J.).

precedents_cited.relevance: Government power to regulate admissions over university eligibility.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chitra Ghosh v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Government can lay down sources for admission; valid classifications.
Valid reservations apart from Art. 15(4), e.g., defence personnel children.
Political sufferers reservation struck down; but definition here clear.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; special provisions for backward classes; writ for fundamental rights.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Medical Colleges Selection for Admission Rules, 1970
statutes_cited.relevance: Admission eligibility, reservations, selection committee, seat distribution.

statutes_cited.name: Karnatak University Ordinance 144A
statutes_cited.relevance: Eligibility for medical course after B.Sc. Part I.

outcome.summary: All five writ petitions challenging validity of Mysore Medical Colleges Selection Rules, 1970 dismissed; rules held valid except Dua J. refrains on Rule 4(h); petitioners not entitled to admission.

key_quotes.text: A candidate may have the minimum qualification so as to make him eligible for entrance in a particular faculty. That does not mean that his being eligible necessarily makes him entitled to admission in that faculty.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes eligibility from right to admission.

key_quotes.text: The Government which bears the financial burden of running the Government colleges is entitled to lay down criteria for admission in its own colleges.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Such a classification has a reasonable nexus with the object of the rules, namely, to cater to the needs of candidates who would naturally look to their own university.
key_quotes.speaker: court
